page.title: List of Irish counties' coats of arms

revisions.rev:
The following is a list of '''Irish counties' coats of arms'''. In the majority of cases these are arms assigned to [[county council]]s created by the [[Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898]] or later legislation, either by the [[Chief Herald of Ireland]] in what is now the [[Republic of Ireland]] or the [[College of Arms]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. All but two [[county council]]s in the Republic has a [[coat of arms]]. In Northern Ireland county councils were abolished in 1973, but the traditional arms are still occasionally used. There are no official county flags. Flags with the [[GAA county colours and flags|GAA county colours]] serve as [[defacto]] county flags. ==History== The earliest Irish county arms date from the late 17th century, when those of counties Carlow, Kilkenny and "Typerary" were recorded by [[Richard Carney]], [[Ulster King of Arms]].Genealogical office Ms.60, ''Some 1150 Tricks of Family arms, with arms of Bishoprics and of counties Carlow, Tipperary and Kilkenny collected by Carney, Ulster about 1668'', folio 190 In each case the arms consist of an ermine shield bearing a ''fesse'' or central horizontal band on which heraldic devices of local families are displayed. The arms of Tipperary became obsolete when the county was divided into North and South Ridings in 1838. When county councils were established in 1899, each was obliged to adopt a seal. In some cases these used an unofficial coat of arms, but no arms were officially granted prior to the splitting of heraldic jurisdiction in 1943.[[Arthur Charles Fox-Davies]], ''The Book of Public Arms'', Second edition, London, 1915 In 1914 a system of county and city flags were designed as unit colours for the [[Irish Volunteers]]. Each county flag was to include a coat of arms, with a list of suggested designs drawn by [[The O'Rahilly]]. While few of these coliours were ever manufactured, some of the county devices were later to occur in official grants.G. A. Hayes-McCoy, ''A History of Irish Flags from Earliest Times'', Dublin, 1979 ===Grants by the Chief Herald of Ireland=== With the establishment of the [[Office of the Chief Herald of Ireland|Genealogical Office]] in 1943, a native Irish heraldic jurisdiction was established. One of the earliest grants by the new office was to Dublin County Council on September 30, 1944. The grant was notable for its use of [[Norsemen|Norse]] symbolism and the [[motto]] in the [[Irish (language)|Irish language]].Susan Hood, ''Royal Roots - Republican Inheritance, the Survival of the Office of Arms'', Dublin, 2002 In 1949 [[Edward MacLysaght]], the Chief Herald, discovered the seventeenth century arms of counties Carlow and Kilkenny, and wrote to the county councils concerned informing of their existence.Genealogical Office Ms 527, MacLysaght Miscellany From 1956 there was a steady flow of grants to county councils. In 1990 [[South Tipperary|Tipperary South Riding County Council]] was granted arms based on those recorded by Richard Carney.Genelogical Office Register of Arms Q (1943-52), Register of Arms R (1952-59), Register of Arms S (1959-66), Register of Arms T (1966-72), Register of Arms U (1973-78), Register of Arms V (1978-81), Register of Arms W+X (1982-95), Register of Arms Y (1996-99) ===Grants by the College of Arms=== In 1943 heraldic jurisdiction in Northern Ireland passed to the College of Arms in London, with the creation of the merged office of [[Norroy and Ulster King of Arms]]. Five out of six of the northern county councils received grants of arms from London. In each case [[supporters]] were also granted.Geoffrey Briggs, ''Civic and Corporate Heraldry'', London, 1971 In all cases these arms became obsolete with the abolition of county councils by the [[Local Government Act (Northern Ireland) 1972]]. ==Coats of arms== ===Connacht=== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Arms !County ![[Blazon]] |- | [[Image:Logogalwayco.png|100px|border]] || [[County Galway|Galway]] || Azure thereon five mullets argent, on waves of the sea in base a Galway hooker in full sail sailing to the sinister all proper, with the motto: ''Ceart agus CÃ³ir''.
Granted 22 June 1993. |- | [[Image:Leitrimcountylogo.png|100px|border]] || [[County Leitrim|Leitrim]] || Per fess double arched or and vert in chief a lion passant sable and in base three fountains.
Certified 1 July 1981. |- | [[Image:Mayococologo.png|100px|border]] || [[County Mayo|Mayo]] || Per fess gules and argent in chief four crosses one and three the first patriarchal the others passion crosses or, in base on waves of the sea a lymphad proper, the whole within a bordure of the third charged with nine yew trees also proper, with the Crest: On a mount vert a garden rose slipped or and with the Motto: ''Dia is Muire linn'' (God and [[Mary (Mother of Jesus)|Mary]] be with us).
Certified 10 March 1981. |- | [[Image:Logo-contea-Roscommon.png|100px|border]] || [[County Roscommon|Roscommon]] || Azure, on a pile vert fimbriated or, between on the dexter a ram's head argent and on the sinister an oak branch proper, a cross patÃ©e concave of the third, in base a antique crown also gold, with the motto: ''CONSTANS HIBERNIAE COR'' (Steadfast Irish heart).
Certified 10 August 1961. |- | [[Image:Sligococo.png|100px|border]] || [[County Sligo|Sligo]] || Sable semÃ©e of escallops argent an open book proper thereon in the dexter a Celtic cross and in the sinister a rose gules, on a point [pointed] in base of the second a boar's head [[Erasure (heraldry)|erased]] of the first armed of the fourth with the motto: ''Land of Heart's Desire''.
Granted 8 September 1982. |} ===Leinster=== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Arms !County ![[Blazon]] |- | [[File:Carlow County Crest.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Carlow|Carlow]] || Ermine on a fess per pale argent and gules on the dexter a lion rampant gules and on the sinister two lions passant guardant Or.
Recorded as arms of County Carlow c.1665 |- | [[File:Dublin crest.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Dublin|Dublin]] || Or, a raven standing upon a hurdle sable; for Crest, a beacon proper and for motto: ''Beart do rÃ©ir Ã¡r mbriathar'' (Action to match our speech).
Granted 30 September 1944.
Became obsolete in 1994 on division into Dun Laoghaire-Rathdown, Fingal and South Dublin. |- | || [[Fingal]] || Vert a raven on a hurdle proper, in chief in the dexter a St. Brigidâs cross and in the sinister a garb Or, on a point enhanced in base argent on waves of the sea in base of four azure and of the fourth a Viking longship sail set also proper, with the motto: ''FlÃºirse Talaimh is Mara'' (Abundance of Land and Sea).
Granted to Fingal Area Committee 26 November 1993. |- | || [[Dun Laoghaire-Rathdown]] || Per chevron argent and vert, in chief an ancient Irish crown proper between in the dexter a slip of oak of the second fructed of the third [=proper] and in the sinister a trefoil slipped also of the second, in base on waves of the sea barry wavy of four of the first and azure a Viking longship sail set oars in action also proper, motto: ''Ã Chuan go Sliabh'' (From Harbour to Mountain).
Granted to Dun Laoghaire â Rathdown Area Committee 7 December 1993. |- | || [[South Dublin]] || Argent two barrulets dancettÃ© vert between as many bars wavy azure in chief an open book proper garnished or the dexter page charged with a Celtic cross gules and in base a fret couped sable with the mottoes: ''This We Hold in Trust'' and above ''Ag Seo Ãr gCÃºram''.
Granted to South Dublin Area Committee 29 June 1993. |- | || [[County Kildare|Kildare]] || Argent on a saltire gules between in chief a saint Brigid's cross vert in base a sprig of oak of the last fructed proper and in fess in the dexter a harp and in the sinister a horse's head erased, both of the last, two swords in saltire points upward gold, with the motto: ''Meanma agus Misneach'' (Spirit and Courage).
Granted 19 July 1991. |- | [[File:Kilkenny County Crest.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Kilkenny|Kilkenny]] || Ermine a fess party per pale dexter sable three garbs argent sinister quarterly 1st and 4th argent 2nd and 3rd gules a fret Or.
Recorded as Arms of County Kilkenny circa 1665. |- | [[File:Laoiscocologo.png|100px|border]] || [[County Laois|Laois]] || Or on a chevron gules between in chief two fountains and in base a lion rampant sable seven ermine spots argent, with the motto: ''I bpÃ¡irt leis an bpobal'' (In partnership with the community).
Granted 16 June 1998. |- | || [[County Longford|Longford]] || Per pale azure and or a castle of two towers counterchanged on a chief wavy per pale of the second and of the first a hound courant also counterchanged with the motto: ''Daingean agus DÃ­lis'' (Strong and Loyal).
Granted 19 July 1988. |- | || [[County Louth|Louth]] || Vert a bezant charged with a dexter hand aversant couped at the wrist proper, on a chief sable two ancient ships sails set argent, with the Crest: Between two ears of barley or conjoined at the base a sword erect point downwards proper and with the motto: ''Lugh sÃ¡imh-ioldÃ¡nach'' ([[Lugh]] equally skilled in many arts).
Certified 9 June 1977. |- | [[File:Meath coa.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Meath|Meath]] || Per pile enarched reversed vert and azure fimbriated argent, at the fess point an antique crown or in chief in the dexter a spiral, in the sinister a Celtic cross and in base a salmon naiant all of the third, the whole within a bordure gold with the motto: ''TrÃ© Neart le ChÃ©ile'' (Together Strong).
Granted 16 September 1988. |- | [[File:Offaly crest.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Offaly|Offaly]] || Tierced in fess vert, argent and or, a lion rampant holding between the paws a cross patÃ©e concave all of the last, the cross within an annulet of the second, on a point pointed in base sable a sprig of Andromeda polifolia proper, with the motto: ''ESTO FIDELIS'' (Be Faithful).
Granted 31 August 1983. |- | [[File:Westmeath logo 01.JPG|100px|border]] || [[County Westmeath|Westmeath]] || Per saltire azure and gules, in the fess point an annulet between two lions rampant and respecting each other all or, in chief a swan swimming and in base a Norse helmet both proper, with the motto: ''Triath Ã³s Triathaibh'' (Noble above nobility).
Certified 7 August 1968. |- | [[File:IRL COA County Wexford 3D.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Wexford|Wexford]] || Per bend purpure and or, on a band wavy argent between in chief a lion rampant holding in the paws a pike of the last and on rocks in base a representation of the Hook Lighthouse all proper, two spear heads bendwise points upwards also proper, with the motto: ''Exemplar Hiberniae'' (An example to Ireland).
Granted 19 July 1988. |- | [[File:Wicklowcocoarms.png|100px|border]] || [[County Wicklow|Wicklow]] || Per fess dancetÃ©e azure and vert, in chief a lion passant to the sinister reguardant Or between two oak branches proper, in base a representation of St. Kevin's Church at Glendalough proper with the motto: ''Meanma Saor'' (Free Spirits).
Certified 1 August 1956. |} ===Munster=== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Arms !County ![[Blazon]] |- | [[File:County Clare Crest.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Clare|Clare]] || Per fesse dancetÃ©e azure and or on a pale counter-changed between in chief in the dexter a rose and in the sinister an antique crown of the second and in base in the dexter an annulet rayonÃ©e and in the sinister a stagâs head erased gules, in chief a tau cross proper and in base a pile reversed of the second fleuried at the point argent; a point pointed barry wavy of the last and of the first and with the motto: ''DÃ­lis d'ar nOidhreacht'' (True to our heritage).
Granted 6 September 1985. |- | || [[County Cork|Cork]] || The county council has no arms. The seal was adopted in 1899: In the centre are the arms of Cork City. The other six shields are arms of towns in the county, although none have been officially recorded. These represent Youghal, Castlemartyr, Bandon, Midleton, Kinsale and Charleville.''Cork County Guide'', c.1990 |- | [[Image:Kerrycocologo.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Kerry|Kerry]] || Per fess vert and or a fess indented point in point argent and azure between in chief an antique crown of the second between two cross crosslets fitchÃ©e of the third and in base a representation of the boat of St. Brendan of the first, with the motto: ''Comhar, Cabhair, Cairdeas'' (Co-operation, Help, Friendship).
Granted 12 April 1984. |- | || [[County Limerick|Limerick]] || Vert three pallets wavy argent, a cross patÃ©e convexed within an annulet Or, with the crest: A figure of [[Patrick Sarsfield]], the right hand grasping a sword, the left hand outstretched and pointing, all proper and with the motto: ''Cuimhnigh ar Luimneach'' (Remember Limerick).
Certified 24 May 1976. |- | [[Image:IRL county Tipperary COA.png|100px|border]] || [[County Tipperary]] || Ermine a fesse quarterly 1 and 4 Or a chief indented azure 2 and 3 gules three covered cups gold.
Recorded as Arms of County Tipperary c.1665.
These arms became obsolete when the county was divided in 1838. |- | || [[North Tipperary]] || The county council has no coat of arms. |- | || [[South Tipperary]] || Per fess ermine and barry wavy of six argent and azure, a fess quarterly, first and fourth quarters or a chief indented azure, second and third quarters gules three covered cups or, and in base three salmon naiant two and one proper, with the crest: A lion couchant or langued gules and with the motto: ''Vallis Aurea Suirensis'' (The Golden Vale of the [[River Suir|Suir]]).
Granted to Tipperary South Riding County Council 6 July 1990. |- | || [[County Waterford|Waterford]] || Azure on a pile reversed throughout argent, between in the dexter an eagleâs head erased of the second holding in the beak three stalks of wheat or and in the sinister a stagâs head erased also of the second holding in the beak three stalks of wheat or and in the sinister a stagâs head erased also of the second thereon between the attires a Latin cross of the third, a representation of the round tower of Ardmore proper, on a point in base barry-wavy of six of the first and second a lymphad, sail set, oars in action, flags flying gold with the motto: ''DÃ©isi oc DeclÃ¡n co BrÃ¡th'' (May the [[DÃ©ise]] remain with [[Declan]] forever).
Granted 4 February 1997. |} ===Ulster=== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Arms !County ![[Blazon]] |- | [[File:Antrim arms.png|100px|border]] || [[County Antrim|Antrim]] (NI) || Or a lion rampant gules holding in the dexter paw a cross crosslet fitchÃ©e azure; on a chief vert between two towers a pale argent thereon a dexter hand appaumÃ©e gules and for a Crest On a wreath of the colours, A demi figure representing [[St. Patrick]] in a habit vert trimmed with gold, the nimbus or holding in the dexter hand a slip of shamrock and supporting over the sinister shoulder a shepherdâs crook proper. Supporters: On either side a wolf gules, that on the dexter holding in the mouth a slip of flax flowered, that on the sinister a wheat ear both stalked and leaved proper [the whole upon a Compartment of basaltic rock proper, representing the [[Giants Causeway]]. Motto: ''Per angusta ad augusta'' (Through Trial to Triumph).
Granted 28 March 1952 by [[Garter Principal King of Arms|Garter]] and Norroy & Ulster Kings of Arms. |- | [[File:Armagh arms.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Armagh|Armagh]] (NI) || County Armagh has never received a grant of arms. Traditionally the reputed arms of the City of [[Armagh]] were used. These were a blue shield bearing a gold harp (the arms of Ireland). It has been suggested that Armagh used these arms as it is the ecclesiastical capital of Ireland. Sometimes the field of the arms has been depicted as green, identical to the arms of the Province of Leinster. These arms have appeared upon Northern Ireland bank notes representing the county.Nicholas Williams, ''Armas â SracfhÃ©achaint ar Araltas na hÃireann'', Howth, 2001 |- | [[File:Cavan crest.svg|100px|border]] || [[County Cavan|Cavan]] || Party per pale Or and Sable two fountains palewise between in chief two lions counter-rampant and in base a lion passant guardant all counter-changed. With the motto: ''Feardhacht is FÃ­rinne'' (Manliness and Truth).
Certified by Chief Herald 20 September 1979. |- | [[File:Donegalcocologo.png|100px|border]] || [[County Donegal|Donegal]] || Barry wavy of eight vert and or, on an inescutcheon ermine a cross crosslet fitchÃ©e gules, with the Crest: In front of four quill pens erect points downwards or a dove proper, mantled gules doubled argent with the Motto: ''Mutuam habeatis caritatem'' ((Maintain among you) Mutual love or charity) and with the Badge: A cross crosslet fitchÃ©e gules enfiled with a lunula points upwards or.
Certified by Chief Herald 20 May 1974. |- | [[File:Down arms.png|100px|border]] || [[County Down|Down]] (NI) || Vert, on a fess Or fretty Gules a fish naiant Argent, in chief three garbs Or and in base on water barry wavy of four Argent and Azure a lymphad sail furled pennon and flags flying Or between two flax flowers slipped and leaved proper.Crest: On a wreath of the colours, Out of an ancient crown a dexter cubit arm vested and cuffed Argent, the hand proper grasping a Celtic crozier Or, looped about the shaft a snake, head downwards and to the sinister Vert.Supporters: On either side an Irish Elk guardant proper. Motto: ''Absque Labore Nihil'' (Nothing Without Labour).
Granted by Garter and Norroy & Ulster 15 December 1967. |- | [[File:Ferm arms.png|100px|border]] || [[County Fermanagh|Fermanagh]] (NI) || Barry wavy argent and azure, two flaunches vert; over all a representation of the Watergate at [[Enniskillen]] Or, flying from the battlements to the dexter a banner of St. Patrick and for a crest out of a coronet of four shamrocks set upon a rim Or a mount vert, thereon a horse passant argent, caparisoned gules, thereon a knight in full armour, in the dexter hand a sword erect proper [hilt and pomel Or.] Supporters: On either side a brock proper charged on the shoulder with a bezant, thereon a dexter hand couped gules. Motto: ''FEOR MAGH EANAGH''.
Granted by Garter and Norroy & Ulster 20 August 1954. |- | [[File:Lderry co arms.png|100px|border]] || [[County Londonderry|Londonderry]] (NI) || Per chevron Gules and Or, in chief a flax flower proper between two garbs of the second, in base a dexter hand appaumÃ©e couped at the wrist of the first; the shield ensigned with a mural crown gold. Supporters: On either side a sea dragon argent, each charged on the wing with a cross Gules and wreathed about the neck with a garland of oak stalked and leaved and fructed proper. Motto: ''Auxilium A Domino'' (Help comes from the Lord).
Granted by Garter and Norroy & Ulster 1 February 1951. |- | || [[County Monaghan|Monaghan]] || Per pale azure and argent, in the dexter an ancient Irish shield or and in the sinister a horseâs head erased sable; on a chief per pale of the second and of the first, in the dexter a sword in bend sinister point upwards proper and in the sinister an ancient Irish drinking cup of the third and with the Motto: ''DÃºthracht agus DÃ­cheall'' (Diligence and Best Endeavour).
Granted by chief Herald 10 January 1984. |- | [[File:Tyrone arms.png|100px|border]] || [[County Tyrone|Tyrone]] (NI) || Per fesse indented Sable and Argent, in chief a mullet of eight points of the second charged with a fleur-de-lys of the first, in base a dexter hand appaumÃ©e Gules. Crest: On a wreath Argent and Gules, On a mount and in front of a castle of two towers, a hurst, issuant from the battlements of the castle a dexter arm embowed in armour, the hand grasping a sword in bend sinister, all proper. Supporters: On either side a lion rampant, that to the dexter Or gorged with a ribbon, pendent therefrom an escutcheon Argent charged with a cross Gules, and that to the sinister Gules gorged with a ribbon Argent, pendent therefrom an escutcheon Azure charged with a saltire also Argent. Motto: ''Consilio et Prudentia'' (By Wisdom and Prudence).
Granted by Garter and Norroy & Ulster 24 May 1951. |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Irish Counties' Coats Of Arms}} [[Category:Counties of Ireland]] [[Category:Ireland-related lists|Counties' coats of arms]] [[Category:Lists of coats of arms]]
